prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: N1365bar
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Will do mosaic on the stellar bar of the galaxy NGC1365 in CO(2-1).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We will make a large mosaic (~220"x90") to map the bar at a 0.6" resolution.
[Sensitivity] Our target sensitivity is sigma=0.5K for dV=5 km/s. This is to make five sigma detection of H2 surface density of 20 Msun/pc^2 in a 5 km/s channel for alpha_co=1.6 Msun/pc^2 (K km/s)^-1. The surface density is >~ 5 times lower than the typical mean surface density of GMCs in our Galaxy and hence should allow us to detect diffuse gas or smaller-than-beam clouds at lower-than-GMC mean surface density. This is also about 3 times deeper than our pilot SMA observations
[Imaging] The bar is large and we do mosaic. Even considering galaxy rotation, we need ACA and TP, as suggested by the OT.
[Calibration/bandpass] nothing special.
[Correlator setup] We will use 1875 MHz coverage and 1 MHz (1.2km/s) channel spacing for all four basebands. The spectral resolution, ~2.5km/s, is just right for the small clouds we could detect. Line width vary and is larger near the galactic center. We put CO(2-1) in BB1, H30alpha in BB2, CS(5-4) in BB3, and CH3OH in BB4, though only CO is certain to be detected.
[Scheduling time] no constraint.
[Data rate] 12MB/s. Our mapping area contains the galactic center and we go deeper than our SMA pilot observations. Thus we may well see lines we did not expect. Those weaker lines, if detected, are still valuable for ISM diagnosis. Considering how expensive the ALMA time is, we do not want to throw out their potential velocity information by using the TDM mode whose velocity resolution (=2*channel spacing) is about 80 km/s, too poor for our work.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: N1365cmz
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Will do a small mosaic on and around the CMZ of the galaxy NGC 1365 in CO(2-1)

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We will make a small mosaic (~80"x30") to encompass the CMZ at a higher 0.3" resolution.
[Sensitivity] Our target sensitivity is sigma=0.5K for dV=20 km/s. The larger velocity width for the same rms Tb as our larger mosaic is because molecular clouds in the CMZs are generally more turbulent than those in the disk, while having comparable or higher brightness temperature. The total line width of 100 km/s is possible for a clump [Sak07]. The rms sensitivity for a dV=100 km/s channel corresponds to rms mass surface density of 35 Msun/pc^2. Clouds with very high-surface densities of several 100 Msun/pc^2 across our 0.3" beam will be firmly detected and their parameters including line width can be measured with this sensitivity.
[Imaging] We do mosaic to cover the CMZ area. However, we do not ask for ACA and/or TP because our primary target here is compact, CO luminous, cluster-forming clouds. If we later find a need for short baseline information for this 0.3" resolution data, we will manually combine our bar-mosaic data.
[Calibration/bandpass] nothing special.
[Correlator setup] We will use 1875 MHz coverage and 1 MHz (1.2km/s) channel spacing for all four basebands. We will put CO(2-1) in BB1, H30alpha in BB2, CS(5-4) in BB3, and CH3OH in BB4, though only CO is certain to be detected.
[Scheduling time] no constraint.
[Data rate] 12MB/s. We here map the CMZ at 0.3" resolution and hence will have 4 times less beam dilution for compact sources than in our 0.6" mosaic. Thus we may well see lines we did not expect. Those weaker lines, if detected, are still valuable for ISM diagnosis. Considering how expensive the ALMA time is, we do not want to throw out their potential velocity information by using the TDM mode whose velocity resolution (=2*channel spacing) is about 80 km/s, too poor even in CMZ (because line widths can be hardly measured.)

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: M83bar
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Will do mosaic on the stellar bar of the galaxy M83 in CO(2-1).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We will make a large mosaic (~220"x90") to map the bar at a 0.6" resolution.
[Sensitivity] Our target sensitivity is sigma=0.5K for dV=5 km/s. This is to make five sigma detection of H2 surface density of 20 Msun/pc^2 in a 5 km/s channel for alpha_co=1.6 Msun/pc^2 (K km/s)^-1. The surface density is >~ 5 times lower than the typical mean surface density of GMCs in our Galaxy and hence should allow us to detect diffuse gas or smaller-than-beam clouds at lower-than-GMC mean surface density. This is also about 3 times deeper than our pilot SMA observations
[Imaging] The bar is large and we do mosaic. Even considering galaxy rotation, we need ACA and TP, as suggested by the OT.
[Calibration/bandpass] nothing special.
[Correlator setup] We will use 1875 MHz coverage and 1 MHz (1.2km/s) channel spacing for all four basebands. The spectral resolution, ~2.5km/s, is just right for the small clouds we could detect. Line width vary and is larger near the galactic center. We put CO(2-1) in BB1, H30alpha in BB2, CS(5-4) in BB3, and CH3OH in BB4, though only CO is certain to be detected.
[Scheduling time] no constraint.
[Data rate] 12MB/s. Our mapping area contains the galactic center and we go deeper than our SMA pilot observations. Thus we may well see lines we did not expect. Those weaker lines, if detected, are still valuable for ISM diagnosis. Considering how expensive the ALMA time is, we do not want to throw out their potential velocity information by using the TDM mode whose velocity resolution (=2*channel spacing) is about 80 km/s, too poor for our work.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: M83cmz
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Will do a small mosaic on and around the CMZ of the galaxy M83 in CO(2-1).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We will make a small mosaic (~80"x30") to encompass the CMZ at a higher 0.3" resolution.
[Sensitivity] Our target sensitivity is sigma=0.5K for dV=20 km/s. The larger velocity width for the same rms Tb as our larger mosaic is because molecular clouds in the CMZs are generally more turbulent than those in the disk, while having comparable or higher brightness temperature. The total line width of 100 km/s is possible for a clump [Sak07]. The rms sensitivity for a dV=100 km/s channel corresponds to rms mass surface density of 35 Msun/pc^2. Clouds with very high-surface densities of several 100 Msun/pc^2 across our 0.3" beam will be firmly detected and their parameters including line width can be measured with this sensitivity.
[Imaging] We do mosaic to cover the CMZ area. However, we do not ask for ACA and/or TP because our primary target here is compact, CO luminous, cluster-forming clouds. If we later find a need for short baseline information for this 0.3" resolution data, we will manually combine our bar-mosaic data.
[Calibration/bandpass] nothing special.
[Correlator setup] We will use 1875 MHz coverage and 1 MHz (1.2km/s) channel spacing for all four basebands. We will put CO(2-1) in BB1, H30alpha in BB2, CS(5-4) in BB3, and CH3OH in BB4, though only CO is certain to be detected.
[Scheduling time] no constraint.
[Data rate] 12MB/s. We here map the CMZ at 0.3" resolution and hence will have 4 times less beam dilution for compact sources than in our 0.6" mosaic. Thus we may well see lines we did not expect. Those weaker lines, if detected, are still valuable for ISM diagnosis. Considering how expensive the ALMA time is, we do not want to throw out their potential velocity information by using the TDM mode whose velocity resolution (=2*channel spacing) is about 80 km/s, too poor even in CMZ (because line widths can be hardly measured.)

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose subarcsec-resolution wide-field imaging of the entire stellar bars in two prototypical barred spiral galaxies. Our main goals are (1) the gas dynamics in bars to channel molecular gas to the central molecular zones (CMZs), and (2) ISM reactions to the bar-driven gas dynamics in the bars and in the star-forming CMZs including cloud formation leading to the formation of young massive clusters (YMCs). Our targets, M83 and NGC 1365, have face-on stellar bars of large ~4 arcmin extent on the southern sky. They will be fully mapped in CO(2-1) at linear resolutions of 10 and 50 pc, respectively, without missing any extended emission. Their CMZs will be imaged at twice higher resolutions through additional targeted observations. This project is going to reveal unprecedented details of the molecular gas behavior in galactic bars of moderate and large lengths (~5 and 20 kpc, respectively) and uncover the relation between gas dynamics, molecular cloud properties, and star cluster formation.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Institute of Astronomy and Astrophysics, Academia Sinica

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: IBM T. J. Watson Research Center
Nobeyama Radio Observatory, National Astronomical Observatory of Japan
The Carnegie Observatories, Carnegie Institution of Washington
Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory, Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics
Institute of Astronomy and Astrophysics, Academia Sinica
Faculty of Science and Technology, Keio University
Department of Physics, National Tsing-Hua University
